pullRequest.body:
Prove a stronger version of Vitali's convergence theorem, which does not require an `IsFiniteMeasure` hypothesis. Instead it uses a new uniform tightness hypothesis. The hypothesis `UnifTight` is implemented closely following the structure of the existing `UnifIntegrable`.

---

- [x] depends on: #14570
- [x] depends on: #14646
- [x] depends on: #14954

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Thanks a lot for the PR! Sorry that it tooks weeks to react to it. The reason it was missed by the reviewers is that it lacks labels. You should add the `awaiting-review` label to signal the PR is ready for other people to look at it. There is a special queue where only PRs with that label appear, and reviewers tend to look at that queue. When a PR is not yet ready for review, please add the label WIP. Basically never leave a PR without a label.
Also, to help sorting the PRs, adding the topic label `t-measure-probability` is helpful.
I have added these labels for you now.

About the PR: it is quite large and contains parts that should be PRed separately: the coercions between measurability properties is a big change in the way we use them, and should have its own PR. Could you open another PR with those changes, and edit the first message of this PR to note that it depends on the other one?

Thanks, good to know. I tried following the instructions in the [Contributing Guidelines](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html). I wasn't sure that the labels are something for the submitter to choose.

About splitting out the coercions. The main proof doesn't really use them. So if they are somehow against the Mathlib philosophy, they can just be dropped. Or is the point of the separate PR is that's where such a decision would be made?

About the coercions: I don't know yet if they are a good idea or not and a separate PR would be a good place to discuss that.

Making this PR independent of the new coercions would make it simpler to review, so if they are indeed not used much, that would be a good thing to do.

Sorry for a bit of delay. I've removed the measurability coercions from this branch. Now the only code that's outside the UnifTight file is in Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/Pow/NNReal.lean. But it is so minor, it's hardly worth a separate PR, I think.

About the name Uniformly Tight for the new hypothesis. After some thought, I'm not crazy about it. I've chosen it in analogy with the notion of [tight collection of measures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tightness_of_measures), but it might not fit exactly. I'm not expert enough in measure theory to decide which terminology is exactly the right one.
Could you please use explicit terms in `calc` blocks, so that they're readable without looking at the proofs?

> Could you please use explicit terms in `calc` blocks, so that they're readable without looking at the proofs?

Done. I ungolfed the `calc` blocks. Hopefully they are more readable now.

P.S.: Is it good etiquette to merge with the `master` branch when doing updates on a PR? I haven't done it this time.

Fixed the rest of the file (UnifTight.lean). Changed `exists_measurableSet_indicator` to use â‰¤ instead of <, to be more consistent with the definition of `UnifTight` (making it easier to fix the rest of the file).
I asked @RemyDegenne to have another look at the final statement. I'll review the style tomorrow.

A note about terminology. Is `UnifTight` an appropriate name for the new hypothesis? I've checked two references [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tightness_of_measures) and Fremlin (258Xj, Measure Theory vol.2). Both define the term '(uniformly) tight' for a family of _measures_, with Fremlin not dropping 'uniformly'. For measures, the property refers to the uniform smallness of the measure assigned to the complement of a _compact_ set on a topological space.

The property that I defined didn't have a name in any references on Vitali's theorem that I've seen, so I named it by close analogy with the notion above. At the moment I'm happy with `UnifTight` as being sufficiently descriptive, specific and not contradicting convention (an equally good alternative could be `TightFamily`). If it is worth trying to avoid a future clash with the similarly named but distinct notion for measures, one could use instead `TightFuncFamily` or `<appropriate namespace>.UnifTight`. Alternatively, the notion for measures could be introduced in the future as `MeasureTheory.Measure.UnifTight`. Just some thoughts...
Let's ask @sgouezel about names and the final statement as well. I will review the style once the main statement is cleared.

`UnifTight` seems to be a good name for that notion (`UniformlyTight` could be perhaps better since more explicit and not too long? But `UnifTight` matches our `UnifIntegrable`, so it's good). Such families of functions are called tight in Royden and Fitzpatrick, Real Analysis, 4th ed (page 98). Their Vitali convergence theorem uses it (same page).

The related measure notion could be simply called `Tight`.
Latest update has responded to all comments.
New update responds to most comments (see individual replies above for details).
I golfed some helpers lemmas. I'll go over the main file on Monday.

> I golfed some helpers lemmas. I'll go over the main file on Monday.

Should the PR switch over to `< Îµ` instead of `â‰¤ Îµ` everywhere? Your last update is mixing the two kinds of inequalities together.

> You would get better feedback if you split off the prerequisites. I see at least three separate prerequisite PRs you could open:
> 
>     * The new lemmas in `Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.NNReal`
>     * The new lemma in `Data.ENNReal.Operations`
>     * The various measure theoretic prerequisites.

It turns out that the new lemmas that I had added in `Data.ENNReal.Operations` and in `Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.NNReal` became unnecessary after the refactoring that was already done earlier. So I just removed them. I think that the only remaining changes that are outside the new `UnifTight.lean` file were moved there through the refactoring and review carried out by @urkud.

I can of course still split the PR, but perhaps Yury can chime in on whether that's really necessary.

> It turns out that the new lemmas that I had added in `Data.ENNReal.Operations` and in `Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.NNReal` became unnecessary after the refactoring that was already done earlier. So I just removed them.

Feel free to open independent PRs for them if you think they are generally useful, though (it happens to me a lot that I write lemmas that I end up not needing, and I usually do PR them anyway).

In general, `snorm'` is not meant to be used outside of the file where it's defined as an intermediate step towards snorm.

The usual way of writing such results in mathlib is with set integrals instead of indicators: `âˆ«â» a in sá¶œ, g a âˆ‚Î¼ â‰¤ ENNReal.ofReal Îµ` ([MeasureTheory.lintegral_indicator](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Integral/Lebesgue.html#MeasureTheory.lintegral_indicator) can be used to go from one to the other).
Fixed in next update.

Let's enter tactic mode directly. It looks cleaner than the `fun Îµ hÎµ â†¦ by` way you have here:
```suggestion
    UnifTight (fun _ : Î¹ => g) p Î¼ := by
  intro Îµ hÎµ
  by_cases hÎµ_top : Îµ = âˆž
```
I was following Yury's lead with this style. :-) My original code use `intro` everywhere. I myself have no strong opinion here.

```suggestion
  Â· exact âŸ¨âˆ…, by measurability, fun _ => hÎµ_top.symm â–¸ le_topâŸ©
```

Please use `refine` instead of `refine'` (everywhere in the PR).
```suggestion
  refine âŸ¨s, ne_of_lt hÎ¼s, fun j => ?_âŸ©
```
Done in next update.
This lemma should go to `MeasureTheory/Integral/Lebesgue`.
Moved to `MeasureTheory.Integral.Lebesgue`. Had to introduce some auxiliary lemmas to work with the weaker hypotheses.

Here's a short [Zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113489-new-members/topic/Simplify.20proof.20with.20ENNReal) on how to potentially simplify the new `add_sub_add_comm` lemma in `Data.ENNReal.Real`.

```suggestion
    âˆƒ s : Set Î±, MeasurableSet s âˆ§ Î¼ s < âˆž âˆ§
```

We try to assume `â‰  âˆž` and deduce `< âˆž`. Also, can `MeasureTheory.exists_measurable_le_lintegral_eq` help completely drop measurability assumption?
```suggestion
    {g : Î± â†’ â„â‰¥0âˆž} (haemg : AEMeasurable g Î¼) (hg : âˆ«â» a, g a âˆ‚Î¼ â‰  âˆž)
```
Another question: is it true for any absolutely continuous measure, not just `Î¼.withDensity g`?

Changed to `â‰  âˆž`, no problem. I did manage to drop the measurability assumption on `g` as you suggested. But for that I needed to introduce the new lemma `MeasureTheory.exists_measurable_le_set_lintegral_eq_of_integrable` (now in `MeasureTheory.Integral.Lebesgue`), which says that the measurable replacement for `g` is good on every measurable subset, not only globally. But I needed an integrability assumption on `g` for that. It may be possible to get right of the integrability assumption, but I don't see an immediate proof.

I'm not sure about `Î¼.withDensity g` vs any measure absolutely continuous with respect to `Âµ`. If the measure space is Ïƒ-compact, by Radon-Nikodym there is no difference. I don't have a good intuition for what absolute continuity means outside that context.

A generalization: if `M` is a `LinearOrderedCommMonoidWithZero` (in fact, any linear order with `âˆ€ x, 0 â‰¤ x` but we don't have a typeclass for this), `f : Î± â†’ M`, and `g : Î² â†’ M`, then `Tendsto (fun m â†¦ {x | f x < m}.indicator f x) (nhds 0) (pure 0)` (and same for `â‰¤`).

The generalization may be true, but I'm not sure how that generalization would replace `tendsto_ENNReal_indicator_lt` in the proof of `lintegral_indicator_compl_le`. I've left things as they are for now.

This lemma should go to one of the files in `Function/LpSeminorm`. Also, why do you need `hp_one`? I see that you explicitly use it once to prove `0 < p` but for `p = 0` the assumption is trivial, because the seminorm is trivial. Also, please update this lemma to deal with `Îµ : â„â‰¥0âˆž`.
Moved to `MeasureTheory.Function.LpSeminorm.Basic`. Maybe there is a more optimal place for it. Also removed the `(hp_one : 1 â‰¤ p)` hypothesis, here and in a few other places.

```suggestion
    âˆƒ s : Set Î±, MeasurableSet s âˆ§ Î¼ s < âˆž âˆ§
```
I see that you consider `Îµ = âˆž` separately here and there. Probably, we should change the definition to `âˆ€ Îµ : â„â‰¥0`, not `âˆ€ Îµ : â„â‰¥0âˆž`, then add some casts to the first 2 lemmas.

I don't see any difference between `Îµ : â„â‰¥0` with `0 < Îµ` and `Îµ : â„` with `0 < Îµ` (except that â„ arithmetic is easier to work with), which is what this PR was using originally. The move to `Îµ : â„â‰¥0âˆž` did make some intermediate inequalities simpler by getting rid of casts. Handling the `Îµ = âˆž` separately I think is not a big deal.  I think the only reason to go back would be some definite `Mathlib` convention for `Îµ`, `Î´` hypotheses, which so far I haven't noticed.

The usual trick here is to add `unifTight_of_const` assuming `âˆ€ i j, f i = f j` instead of dealing with `fun _ : Î¹ â†¦ g`. Then you prove the `Subsingleton` version by `unifTight_of_const fun i j â†¦ congr_arg f (Subsingleton.elim i j)`.

Probably this theorem can be gotten rid of altogether. It is only used in one place, `unifTight_fin`. Here I closely replicated the analogous code from `MeasureTheory.Function.UniformIntegrable`. If this code is to be updated, perhaps it would be better to do a common refactor of the `unifTight_*` and `unifIntegrable_*` theorems after this PR is accepted.

The only difference in the names is I guess justified by the difference is in the notation for the inverse. Just to confirm, your recommendation is to just keep the first pair, rather than extend the symmetry to Real and ENNReal?
Yes, keep only the first pair

P.S.: Don't see a way to make a general lemma at the level of `AddLECancellable` unfortunately.

Please never use `1 / x`. This spelling is deprecated (although not `deprecated`) and we would like no new lemma to use it.

Also, when you add such a lemma, please make sure you add all variants, eg here `y < x ^ zâ»Â¹`, `y â‰¤ x ^ zâ»Â¹`, `x ^ zâ»Â¹ â‰¤ y`. (I know the variants of the lemma you want to add already exist, this is just general advice).

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(MeasureTheory/Function): stronger version of Vitali's convergence theorem

nodes.body:
Thanks a lot for the PR! Sorry that it tooks weeks to react to it. The reason it was missed by the reviewers is that it lacks labels. You should add the `awaiting-review` label to signal the PR is ready for other people to look at it. There is a special queue where only PRs with that label appear, and reviewers tend to look at that queue. When a PR is not yet ready for review, please add the label WIP. Basically never leave a PR without a label.
Also, to help sorting the PRs, adding the topic label `t-measure-probability` is helpful.
I have added these labels for you now.

About the PR: it is quite large and contains parts that should be PRed separately: the coercions between measurability properties is a big change in the way we use them, and should have its own PR. Could you open another PR with those changes, and edit the first message of this PR to note that it depends on the other one?

Thanks, good to know. I tried following the instructions in the [Contributing Guidelines](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html). I wasn't sure that the labels are something for the submitter to choose.

About splitting out the coercions. The main proof doesn't really use them. So if they are somehow against the Mathlib philosophy, they can just be dropped. Or is the point of the separate PR is that's where such a decision would be made?

About the coercions: I don't know yet if they are a good idea or not and a separate PR would be a good place to discuss that.

Making this PR independent of the new coercions would make it simpler to review, so if they are indeed not used much, that would be a good thing to do.

Sorry for a bit of delay. I've removed the measurability coercions from this branch. Now the only code that's outside the UnifTight file is in Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/Pow/NNReal.lean. But it is so minor, it's hardly worth a separate PR, I think.

About the name Uniformly Tight for the new hypothesis. After some thought, I'm not crazy about it. I've chosen it in analogy with the notion of [tight collection of measures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tightness_of_measures), but it might not fit exactly. I'm not expert enough in measure theory to decide which terminology is exactly the right one.

I asked @RemyDegenne to have another look at the final statement. I'll review the style tomorrow.

A note about terminology. Is `UnifTight` an appropriate name for the new hypothesis? I've checked two references [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tightness_of_measures) and Fremlin (258Xj, Measure Theory vol.2). Both define the term '(uniformly) tight' for a family of _measures_, with Fremlin not dropping 'uniformly'. For measures, the property refers to the uniform smallness of the measure assigned to the complement of a _compact_ set on a topological space.

The property that I defined didn't have a name in any references on Vitali's theorem that I've seen, so I named it by close analogy with the notion above. At the moment I'm happy with `UnifTight` as being sufficiently descriptive, specific and not contradicting convention (an equally good alternative could be `TightFamily`). If it is worth trying to avoid a future clash with the similarly named but distinct notion for measures, one could use instead `TightFuncFamily` or `<appropriate namespace>.UnifTight`. Alternatively, the notion for measures could be introduced in the future as `MeasureTheory.Measure.UnifTight`. Just some thoughts...
Let's ask @sgouezel about names and the final statement as well. I will review the style once the main statement is cleared.

`UnifTight` seems to be a good name for that notion (`UniformlyTight` could be perhaps better since more explicit and not too long? But `UnifTight` matches our `UnifIntegrable`, so it's good). Such families of functions are called tight in Royden and Fitzpatrick, Real Analysis, 4th ed (page 98). Their Vitali convergence theorem uses it (same page).

The related measure notion could be simply called `Tight`.
The naming and the statement look fine to me.
